title: Android 16 fixes a big privacy flaw in its โapproximateโ location setting
summary: Android 16 makes it harder for apps to infer the locations of rural users from their devicesโ approximate locations.
body: Many Android apps ask for your current location to show you more relevant results or help with directions, but most donโt need your precise GPS coordinates to do the job. Thatโs why Android offers two levels of location accuracy: Precise and Approximate. These options are controlled by two different Android permissions and are intended for different kinds of apps. If an app requests a precise location, Android provides the most accurate estimate it can, usually within 3 to 50 meters (about 10 to 164 feet). If an app requests an approximate location, however, Android will only provide a rough estimate of your deviceโs location, which may only be accurate to within 3 square kilometers (about 1.2 square miles). This is why navigation apps always require your deviceโs precise location, while most other apps can function perfectly well with either.

title: YouTube Music uploads saved my rare songs โ hereโs how
summary: Preserving my music library, one upload at a time.
body: Music collecting and appreciation is a deeply personal hobby. Itโs something very important to me and serves as a snapshot of time and place. Over the years, most of us of a certain vintage have built our music libraries piece by piece, from rare digital downloads and fan remixes to songs that never made it to streaming platforms. Even mixtapes if you, like me, are a 90s or earlier kid. For me, those tracks represent more than nostalgia. Theyโre a record of growing up online, scouring file-sharing forums for one-off singles, MySpace, and now, an ever-growing collection of vinyl records collected during my travels. Every record I collect tells a story. A dusty Cuban jazz album I picked up in Havana, the Japanese city pop release I stumbled upon in a secondhand store in Shibuya, or the deep techno record from a small label in Berlin that went under decades ago. You catch my drift. These albums arenโt just music albums, theyโre memories. And yet, when I want to go back to any of them on the go, itโs not an option. Way too many of them donโt exist anywhere in the digital domain. Not on Spotify, not on Apple Music, and all too often, not even on YouTube.

title: Dear Google: I want my smart glasses to become my food logbook
summary: Because food tracking is still stuck in the manual age
body: I donโt count myself as a fitness-tracking nerd who needs a smartwatch strapped to his wrist every waking second just to log every muscle twitch. I wear mine only while working out, or occasionally when Iโm away from my phone for a bit โ like when itโs in another room โ to avoid missing calls or notifications. Thatโs it. Thatโs the entire purpose of a smartwatch for me. While my watch can track everything from my broken sleep to biking laps โ you know, the calories I burn โ without me lifting a finger, it canโt as seamlessly track the calories that go into me. Iโve always struggled with nutrition tracking. Even though dozens of apps let you log your daily meals, the friction remains. The only wearable that could bridge this wide gap in fitness tracking, I foresee, is smart glasses. And even though Iโm not too fond of making every wearable โsmart,โ if glasses could handle nutrition tracking for me, Iโd happily throw my wallet at them.

title: Fitbitโs food logging is broken right now, but thatโs no excuse for a cheat day
summary: Users are hungry for a fix while Fitbit sorts out the mess.
body: TL;DR Fitbitโs food-logging tools, including search and barcode scanning, are down for many Android and iOS users. Recent and frequent foods still work, but new items can only be added manually with limited nutrition data. Fitbit says engineers are investigating the server-side issue, but thereโs no ETA on a fix yet. Fitbit is more than just a step-tracking watch . In fact, it also helps millions stay on top of their daily nutrition. But if you tried logging meals today and found the search bar empty or the barcode scanner unresponsive, youโre not alone. According to multiple reports , Fitbitโs food-logging system is experiencing a widespread outage affecting both Android and iOS users. Over the past 24 hours, people who rely on Fitbitโs food database or barcode scanner have been unable to search for new items or scan packaged goods. Favorites and recent entries still appear in the Log Food section, but trying to look up anything new typically results in a blank screen or a โfitbit.com is down for maintenanceโ pop-up. Support reps have confirmed this isnโt an isolated glitch and say engineers are actively investigating the issue.

title: Your bedtime scrolling habit might not be wrecking your sleep after all
summary: In big news for phone addicts, new research found no clear link between bedtime screen use and poor sleep in adults.
body: Credit: C. Scott Brown / Android Authority TL;DR A study found no clear link between bedtime phone use and poor sleep in adults. Both regular and occasional bedtime scrollers reported better sleep than moderate users. Researchers say age and how you use your phone may matter more than blue light itself. For years, weโve been warned to ditch our phones well before bedtime, with experts saying the blue light is likely to be detrimental to our sleep quality. Turns out, you might not have to feel so guilty about that final scroll after all. As reported by Gizmodo , a new study titled The Complex Association Between Bedtime Screen Use and Adult Sleep Health found no clear link between nightly screen use and poor sleep among adults. In fact, both occasional and regular bedtime screen users reported better overall sleep health than those who used their phones moderately.

title: This upcoming Google Play Store change could make app reviews actually useful
summary: Google might finally let you search through user-submitted reviews.
body: TL;DR Play Store reviews can be a useful resource for learning about apps, but they lack a search tool. You can currently filter reviews by score, date, or even specific topics, but you canโt add new topics yourself. Itโs not yet functional, but some new code strings in the Play Store app suggest that Googleโs working on a review search tool. Reviews have to be one of the most frustrating-to-navigate components of life online โ one that we nonetheless find ourselves returning to time and time again. When you donโt know exactly what the best option for you is just yet, a good user review can really be illuminating. But finding that good one can sometimes require trudging through screens of low-quality submissions, AI slop, and even the work of paid shills. If youโre looking for some help finding the one review that really speaks to your needs, the Google Play Store appears to be working on a tool that might be right up your alley. title: Leakers just canโt agree if the Galaxy S26 Ultraโs cameras are an upgrade or a downgrade

body: TL;DR A noted leaker has contradicted a recent rumor about the Galaxy S26 Ultraโs camera. According to Ice Universe, the Galaxy S26 Ultraโs 3x telephoto will be downgraded โ and not upgraded, as was recently suggested. They say these changes are made to accommodate the slimmer profile of the upcoming Samsung flagship. There are two cadres of Android flagships. In the first category, brands such as OnePlus work tirelessly to make each new phone appear radically different from its predecessor. In the other category, brands such as Samsung reiterate a proven formula and introduce a new phone with some internal changes and minimal cosmetic variations. In the case of the Galaxy S26, too, weโre witnessing the same pattern repeated, where only minor optimization-oriented tweaks are, once again, expected to take priority over anything radical. That also holds for the camera we see on the Galaxy S26 Ultra, which is expected to undergo only minimal variations โ or so we thought until yesterday, when a leak hinted at one of the four cameras being upgraded . That may turn out to be untrue, as reputed leaker Ice Universe has strongly opposed these leaks.

title: Googleโs proposed Android changes wonโt save sideloading
summary: Google will make the Android app ecosystem more competitive, but it wonโt make sideloading easier.
body: Yesterday, Google and Epic finally reached an agreement to settle their years-long legal dispute. If approved by the judge overseeing the case, the settlement would resolve the lawsuit Epic filed in 2020 to challenge Googleโs stranglehold on Android app distribution. As part of the agreement, Google plans to make sweeping changes to Android, which will be implemented in a future version of next yearโs Android 17 release. The company is developing a new system that will allow users to easily install third-party app stores, reducing the friction of getting apps from outside of Google Play. This timing is notable, as next year is also when Androidโs new developer verification requirements will go into effect. Beginning in September 2026, Android will block users from installing apps made by unverified developers. Although Google says that sideloading isnโt going anywhere, some critics are concerned this change will kill alternative app stores like F-Droid . Thatโs why Googleโs agreement with Epic has sparked hope that Androidโs sideloading restrictions will be eased or eliminated entirely next year.

title: Snapdragon 8 Elite Gen 5 runs hot, and not all phones can handle it

The Nubia REDMAGIC 11 Pro I tested performs within just a few percentage points of Qualcommโs best-case reference model from its launch event, suggesting the new Snapdragon will retain the performance crown for another year. However, thereโs one significant caveat โ graphics stress tests hit blistering highs of 56ยฐC to maintain peak performance over time. Thatโs far too hot to hold the phone comfortably. The only reason the REDMAGIC didnโt buckle under such extreme heat is its elaborate liquid cooling system and fan setup.

title: Android inflates your phoneโs signal strength, but for good reason (Updated)
summary: Google sets the record straight on what those bars really represent.
body: TL;DR A flag in Androidโs Carrier Config Manager allows cellular carriers to artificially inflate the number of bars shown on your phone. Google explains that the majority of carriers require this option, and its addition to the Android codebase dates back to 2017. Android artificially inflates network signal strength to appear as a five-bar scale, rather than the original four-bar scale. Network carriers arenโt afraid to use clever names and marketing to make their cellular performance appear better than it actually is. A prime example is AT&Tโs use of the 5GE badge , which is 4G LTE rather than 5G . The truth is, many carriers use similar strategies to market their cellular networks. A flag in the Android codebase thatโs recently been getting a lot of attention has led some to believe Google was colluding to artificially inflate signal strength, but the true purpose of the flag appears to be much simpler. A report by Nick vs Networking from last month highlighted a flag named KEY_INFLATE_SIGNAL_STRENGTH_BOOL in Androidโs Carrier Config Manager. The Carrier Config Manager explains this flag as determining if the Android system โshould interpret all signal strength as one bar โฆ

title: Google explains the โNano Bananaโ name โ and it wasnโt a grand plan

body: TL;DR Google says โNano Bananaโ began as a late-night placeholder name typed by a PM when submitting the model anonymously. If youโve been wondering why Googleโs viral image editor ended up with the nickname โNano Banana,โ the mysteryโs over. The team says the moniker started life as a throwaway placeholder, and then the internet refused to let it go. On the latest episode of the Made by Google podcast , product lead David Sharon explains that the modelโs official name is Gemini 2.5 Flash Image. However, when a Product Manager named Nina submitted the model anonymously to the LM Arena benchmark website, allowing users to test it out, she had to enter a temporary label that kept it anonymous.
